article_title: Krugman: Rubio is not the GOP's only 'broken record'
article_text:
Krugman: Rubio is not the GOP's only 'broken record' Paul Krugman says the senator's repetitious performance at the debate epitomizes the entire party's reliance on spin and adherence to dogma.

By now everyone who follows politics knows about Marco Rubio's software-glitch performance in Saturday's Republican debate. (I'd say broken-record performance, but that would be showing my age.) Not only did he respond to a challenge from Chris Christie about his lack of achievements by repeating, verbatim, the same line from his stump speech he had used a moment earlier; when Christie mocked his canned delivery, he repeated the same line yet again.

article_metadata.description: Paul Krugman says the senator's repetitious performance at the debate epitomizes the entire party's reliance on spin and adherence to dogma.  In other news, last week - on Groundhog Day, to be precise - Republicans in the House of Representatives cast what everyone knew was a purely symbolic, substance-free vote to repeal Obamacare.  [...] there's the ritual denunciation of Obamacare as a terrible, very bad, no good, job-killing law.  It was tested again when George W. Bush cut taxes on the wealthy; Republicans predicted a "Bush boom" but actually got a lackluster expansion followed by the worst slump since the Great Depression.  Oh, and there's also the spectacular failure of the Kansas experiment, where huge tax cuts have created a budget crisis without delivering any hint of the promised economic miracle.  [...] Republican faith in tax cuts as a universal economic elixir has, if anything, grown stronger, with Rubio, in particular, going even further than the other candidates by promising to eliminate all taxes on capital gains.  Not incidentally, the shared Republican stance on foreign policy is basically the same view Richard Hofstadter famously described in his essay "The Paranoid Style in American Politics": Whenever America fails to impose its will on the rest of the world, it must be because it has been betrayed.
article_metadata.author.name: By Paul Krugman
